nodes.title: Mughal Dynasty
nodes.desc: The Mughal dynasty controls Pakistan and northern India. Urdu is used as a common language for communication, or lingua franca, among the various groups.

nodes.title: The Indian National Congress
nodes.desc: The Indian National Congress is formed to give a voice to the Indian people.

nodes.title: All-India Muslim League
nodes.desc: Mohammed Ali Jinnah forms the All-India Muslim League to ensure Muslims are also represented in Pakistan.

nodes.title: Independence
nodes.desc: India and Pakistan become separate states, which creates a severe demographic shift. Millions of Hindus and Sikhs leave Pakistan and about 8 million Muslim immigrants arrive.

nodes.title: Death of Mohammed Ali Jinnah
nodes.desc: Mohammed Ali Jinnah becomes the first Governor-General of Pakistan until his death the following year.

nodes.title: Urdu Representation
nodes.desc: The governing Muslim League attempts to make Urdu Pakistan's only national language, yet more Pakistanis speak Bengal than Urdu, especially in the east. Riots break out.

nodes.title: Pakistan People's Party
nodes.desc: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto forms the Pakistan People's Party (PPP).

nodes.title: Bangladesh Independence
nodes.desc: Civil war leads to the independence of East Pakistan, now called Bangladesh.

nodes.title: Soviet-Afghan War
nodes.desc: During the Soviet-Afghan War, millions of Afghans flee to Pakistan. There are still approximately 3 million Afghan refugees in the country.

nodes.title: Benazir Bhutto Becomes Prime Minister
nodes.desc: Benazir Bhutto, the daughter of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, becomes the 11th Prime Minister of Pakistan. She is assassinated in 2007.

nodes.title: Pervez Musharraf Seizes Control of the Government
nodes.desc: Pervez Musharraf takes over in a bloodless coup. He resigns his army post in 2007 to become a civilian president.

nodes.title: First Consecutive Democratic Election
nodes.desc: The election marks the first transfer from one democratically elected government to the next.
